Title: Body size affects the evolution of eyespots in caterpillars
Authors: Thomas John Hossie, John Skelhorn, Jesse W Breinholt, Akito Y Kawahara, Thomas N Sherratt
Venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "Artificial caterpillars were designed to quantify the selective advantage of eyespots on large and small prey. Construction of artificial caterpillars followed a methodology similar to that used in previous studies (11,12)."
  - "The dark and light pastries were rolled into strips of 3.5 mm diameter for small prey and 5 mm diameter for large prey, and then cut into lengths of 20 mm for small prey and 40 mm for large prey. Two-toned (i.e., countershaded) prey were then created by pressing together one piece of dark pastry and one piece of light pastry, such that the final artificial prey were cylinders 20 mm long × 5 mm diameter for small prey and 40 mm × 7 mm for large prey."
  - "Pastry caterpillars were manufactured with a 3:1 mixture of white flour and lard. Light-green pastry was produced by adding three drops of Leaf Green AmeriColor Soft Gel Paste (AmeriColor) and 20 mL of water to 40 mL of lard and 118 mL flour; dark-green pastry was produced by adding six drops of gel paste and 15 mL of water to the same volumes of flour and lard."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper indicates that the authors used artificial caterpillar models in both their field and laboratory experiments. In the field experiment, the authors describe the construction of "Pastry caterpillars" made from a mixture of flour and lard, with the models being countershaded and some having eyespots painted on them. In the laboratory experiment, the authors used similar artificial caterpillar models made from pastry.

"Artificial caterpillars were designed to quantify the selective advantage of eyespots on large and small prey. Construction of artificial caterpillars followed a methodology similar to that used in previous studies (11,12)."

"Pastry caterpillars were manufactured with a 3:1 mixture of white flour and lard. Light-green pastry was produced by adding three drops of Leaf Green AmeriColor Soft Gel Paste (AmeriColor) and 20 mL of water to 40 mL of lard and 118 mL flour; dark-green pastry was produced by adding six drops of gel paste and 15 mL of water to the same volumes of flour and lard."

"The dark and light pastries were rolled into strips of 3.5 mm diameter for small prey and 5 mm diameter for large prey, and then cut into lengths of 20 mm for small prey and 40 mm for large prey. Two-toned (i.e., countershaded) prey were then created by pressing together one piece of dark pastry and one piece of light pastry, such that the final artificial prey were cylinders 20 mm long × 5 mm diameter for small prey and 40 mm × 7 mm for large prey."

Title: Deflective effect and the effect of prey detectability on anti-predator function of eyespots
Authors: Adrian Vallin, Marina Dimitrova, Ullasa Kodandaramaiah, Sami Merilaita, D Kemp
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "artificial, triangular prey items"
  - "we used artificial, triangular prey items and blue tits (Cyanistes caeruleus) as predators."
  - "The prey items were isosceles triangular (b × h: 30×15 mm 2 ), and their grey ground color was identical to the grey of the concealing background (Fig. 1b, c ). In addition, there were three lines and nine dots, identical to the lines and dots of the concealing background, randomly distributed on each prey item."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper states that the authors used "artificial, triangular prey items" for their experiments:
"We used artificial, triangular prey items and blue tits (Cyanistes caeruleus) as predators."
The paper also provides details on how the prey items were made:
"The prey items were isosceles triangular (b × h: 30×15 mm 2 ), and their grey ground color was identical to the grey of the concealing background (Fig. 1b, c ). In addition, there were three lines and nine dots, identical to the lines and dots of the concealing background, randomly distributed on each prey item."
From these quotes, it is clear that the authors used artificial, geometrical prey items rather than real butterflies or moths. The prey items were triangular in shape and had a grey ground color with additional patterning elements.

Title: Eyespots interact with body colour to protect caterpillar-like prey from avian predators
Authors: Thomas John Hossie, Thomas N Sherratt
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess the protective value of eyespots and countershading on caterpillar prey in general; however, for ecological relevance, our prey were modelled loosely on Papilio canadensis."
  - "Finished pastry caterpillars (e.g. Fig. 1 ) were checked against a standard model prey for each treatment to ensure uniformity in size and shape of the body, as well as the size and position of eyespots."
  - "Specifically, pastry caterpillars were manufactured with a 3:1 mixture of white flour (White RoseÔ, White Rose Flour Mills, Byford, WA, U.S.A.) and lard (TenderflakeÔ, Maple Leaf Foods, Toronto, ON, Canada)."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper states that the authors used artificial caterpillar prey made from a mixture of flour and lard, rather than real caterpillars:
"Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess the protective value of eyespots and countershading on caterpillar prey in general; however, for ecological relevance, our prey were modelled loosely on Papilio canadensis."
"Specifically, pastry caterpillars were manufactured with a 3:1 mixture of white flour (White RoseÔ, White Rose Flour Mills, Byford, WA, U.S.A.) and lard (TenderflakeÔ, Maple Leaf Foods, Toronto, ON, Canada)."
"Finished pastry caterpillars (e.g. Fig. 1 ) were checked against a standard model prey for each treatment to ensure uniformity in size and shape of the body, as well as the size and position of eyespots."
The paper clearly states that the authors used artificial, pastry-based caterpillar prey rather than real caterpillars.

Title: Field experiments on the effectiveness of 'eyespots' as predator deterrents
Authors: Martin Stevens, Elinor Hopkins, William Hinde, Amabel Adcock, Yvonne Connolly, Tom Troscianko, Innes C Cuthill, K T Troscianko
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "For all experiments, artificial moth-like stimuli (not designed to mimic any real species) were made from triangular pieces of waterproof card (HP LaserJet Tough Paper; Hewlett Packard, Palo Alto, CA, U.S.A.), 50 mm wide at the base and 25 mm high, printed with specific patterns on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 4050N printer."
  - "All treatments, including the controls, appeared highly conspicuous against the tree-trunks on which they were placed."
  - "Eyespots were created in the Java-based imaging program ImageJ (Rasband 1997e2006;Abra `moff et al. 2004), and Photoshop Elements 1.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA, U.S.A.). On each noncontrol target was a pair of eyespots, approximately 7 mm in diameter and 12 mm from the target midline."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper indicates that the authors used artificial "moth-like stimuli" rather than real butterflies or moths. This is evident from the following quotes:

"For all experiments, artificial moth-like stimuli (not designed to mimic any real species) were made from triangular pieces of waterproof card (HP LaserJet Tough Paper; Hewlett Packard, Palo Alto, CA, U.S.A.), 50 mm wide at the base and 25 mm high, printed with specific patterns on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 4050N printer."

"Eyespots were created in the Java-based imaging program ImageJ (Rasband 1997e2006;Abra `moff et al. 2004), and Photoshop Elements 1.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA, U.S.A.). On each noncontrol target was a pair of eyespots, approximately 7 mm in diameter and 12 mm from the target midline."

"All treatments, including the controls, appeared highly conspicuous against the tree-trunks on which they were placed."

The paper clearly states that the authors used artificial moth-like stimuli, rather than real butterflies or moths. Therefore, the "Type prey" is artificial.

Title: Significance of butterfly eyespots as an anti-predator device in ground-based and aerial attacks
Authors: Anne Lyytinen, Paul M Brakefield, Johanna Mappes
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "To test whether eyespots affect the escape probability of butterflies after the attack, three forms (spotless, spotted, Bigeye-comet) of B. anynana differing in eyespot pattern, were placed one at a time on the slice of banana into the cages in the presence of a lizard."
  - "Bicyclus anynana (Satyrinae) shows variation in number, size, shape, colour composition, and position of eyespots (Brakefield and French 1999). For its natural range, in central Africa, an alternation of warm, wet and cool, dry seasons is characteristic. The larvae respond to high or low rearing temperatures by developing the spotted or spotless wings of the adult, respectively (Brakefield andLarsen 1984, Brakefield andReitsma 1991). The wet season form has seven eyespots on its hindwings and two on its forewings (Fig. 1 ). In the dry season form these eyespots are reduced in size or totally absent, the wings being uniformly brown. Furthermore, the resting butterfly covers the posterior forewing spot with its hindwings. In addition, we used a double mutant line, Bigeye-comet, in which all the eyespots are larger in size than in the wet season form."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper indicates that the authors used live specimens of the butterfly species Bicyclus anynana, as well as a mutant line of the same species called "Bigeye-comet" which had larger eyespots. This is evident from the following quotes:

"Bicyclus anynana (Satyrinae) shows variation in number, size, shape, colour composition, and position of eyespots (Brakefield and French 1999). For its natural range, in central Africa, an alternation of warm, wet and cool, dry seasons is characteristic. The larvae respond to high or low rearing temperatures by developing the spotted or spotless wings of the adult, respectively (Brakefield andLarsen 1984, Brakefield andReitsma 1991). The wet season form has seven eyespots on its hindwings and two on its forewings (Fig. 1 ). In the dry season form these eyespots are reduced in size or totally absent, the wings being uniformly brown. Furthermore, the resting butterfly covers the posterior forewing spot with its hindwings. In addition, we used a double mutant line, Bigeye-comet, in which all the eyespots are larger in size than in the wet season form."

"To test whether eyespots affect the escape probability of butterflies after the attack, three forms (spotless, spotted, Bigeye-comet) of B. anynana differing in eyespot pattern, were placed one at a time on the slice of banana into the cages in the presence of a lizard."

The paper clearly states that the authors used live specimens of the butterfly species Bicyclus anynana, as well as a mutant line of the same species called "Bigeye-comet". Therefore, the "Type prey" in this study was real, as it involved the use of real butterflies.

Title: The Feeding Behaviour of Starlings (Sturnus vulgaris) in the Presence of 'Eyes'
Authors: I R Inglis, L W Huson, M B Marshall, P A Arid,  Neville
Supporting quotes for "Type prey": - "The four stimuli were a) a blank card; b) two crosses arranged horizontally 6 cm apart, each measuring 2 x~ 2 cm; c) two triangular eyes arranged 6 cm apart, each consisting of an equilateral trianslc having sides 2 c m long and containing a black triangular 'pupil'; d) two circular eyes arranged 6 cm apart, each consisting of a circle of 2 cm diameter containing 1 cm diameter black 'pupil'."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper does not mention using any real butterfly, moth, or caterpillar species or patterns. Instead, it describes using various artificial eye-like patterns drawn on white boards, such as:
"The four stimuli were a) a blank card; b) two crosses arranged horizontally 6 cm apart, each measuring 2 x~ 2 cm; c) two triangular eyes arranged 6 cm apart, each consisting of an equilateral trianslc having sides 2 c m long and containing a black triangular 'pupil'; d) two circular eyes arranged 6 cm apart, each consisting of a circle of 2 cm diameter containing 1 cm diameter black 'pupil'."
The paper also mentions using a "pair of 2-cm diameter eyes with 1 cm diameter 'pupils', arranged horizontally 6 cm apart" and other artificial eye-like patterns.

Title: The position of eyespots and thickened segments influence their protective value to caterpillars
Authors: John Skelhorn, Giles Dorrington, Thomas J Hossie, Thomas N Sherratt
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess whether the position of either eyespots or the thickened body segments associated with the defensive posture, influenced their antipredatory benefit."
  - "Countershaded prey with dark dorsal and light ventral sides (4 cm long with a diameter of ≈0.7 cm) was produced by pressing together dark and light pastry cylinders (4 cm long with a diameter of ≈0.5 cm)."
  - "We followed Hossie and Sherratt's (2013) method of producing countershaded pastry caterpillars based loosely on the appearance of the late instars of Papilio canadensis and Papilio glaucus caterpillars."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper states that the authors used "artificial caterpillars" to conduct their experiments:
"Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess whether the position of either eyespots or the thickened body segments associated with the defensive posture, influenced their antipredatory benefit."
"We followed Hossie and Sherratt's (2013) method of producing countershaded pastry caterpillars based loosely on the appearance of the late instars of Papilio canadensis and Papilio glaucus caterpillars."
"Countershaded prey with dark dorsal and light ventral sides (4 cm long with a diameter of ≈0.7 cm) was produced by pressing together dark and light pastry cylinders (4 cm long with a diameter of ≈0.5 cm)."
Based on these quotes, the authors used artificial, pastry-based caterpillar models rather than real caterpillars or modified patterns of real caterpillars.

Title: The protective value of conspicuous signals is not impaired by shape, size, or position asymmetry
Authors: Martin Stevens, Sarah A Castor-Perry, Jessica R F Price
Supporting quotes for "Type prey":
- "artificial ''prey,'' 76 mm wide and 38 mm high, made from triangular pieces of waterproof paper (HP LaserJet Tough Paper, Palo Alto, CA)."
  - "The experiment followed the same overall procedure as Stevens et al. (2007) and Stevens, Hardman, and Stubbins (2008) , with gray-scale artificial ''prey,'' 76 mm wide and 38 mm high, made from triangular pieces of waterproof paper (HP LaserJet Tough Paper, Palo Alto, CA)."
  - "These were printed with specific patterns, made in Image J (Rasband 1997 (Rasband -2007;; Abra `moff et al. 2004) and Photoshop Elements 2.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA), on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 2200dn printer at 300 dpi."
  - "We created prey that had either a pair of circular spots symmetrical (S) in size (each 80 mm 2 ) or spots with 5% (82 and 78 mm 2 ), 10% (84 and 76 mm 2 ), 25% (90 and 70 mm 2 ), and 50% (100 and 60 mm 2 ) asymmetries (treatments A5, A10, A25, and A50, respectively)."
  - "printed with specific patterns, made in Image J (Rasband 1997 (Rasband -2007;; Abra `moff et al. 2004) and Photoshop Elements 2.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA), on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 2200dn printer at 300 dpi."
Reasoning for "Type prey":
The paper states that the authors used "artificial 'prey,' 76 mm wide and 38 mm high, made from triangular pieces of waterproof paper (HP LaserJet Tough Paper, Palo Alto, CA)." This indicates that the prey used in the experiments were artificial, not real butterfly/moth/caterpillar specimens or patternings. The paper also mentions that the prey were "printed with specific patterns, made in Image J (Rasband 1997 (Rasband -2007;; Abra `moff et al. 2004) and Photoshop Elements 2.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA), on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 2200dn printer at 300 dpi." This further confirms that the prey were artificial, computer-generated patterns printed on paper.

"We created prey that had either a pair of circular spots symmetrical (S) in size (each 80 mm 2 ) or spots with 5% (82 and 78 mm 2 ), 10% (84 and 76 mm 2 ), 25% (90 and 70 mm 2 ), and 50% (100 and 60 mm 2 ) asymmetries (treatments A5, A10, A25, and A50, respectively)."
"The experiment followed the same overall procedure as Stevens et al. (2007) and Stevens, Hardman, and Stubbins (2008) , with gray-scale artificial ''prey,'' 76 mm wide and 38 mm high, made from triangular pieces of waterproof paper (HP LaserJet Tough Paper, Palo Alto, CA)."
"These were printed with specific patterns, made in Image J (Rasband 1997 (Rasband -2007;; Abra `moff et al. 2004) and Photoshop Elements 2.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA), on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 2200dn printer at 300 dpi."
